title: How to Raise Vegetarian Children

methods.name: Helping Your Kids Make the Switch

steps.headline: Talk to your pediatrician before you change their diet.
steps.description: Before you make any major changes to your childrens’ diets, you should talk to your pediatrician. That way, the doctor can make any specific recommendations tailored to each child’s health needs. In addition, the doctor will know to look for specific nutritional deficiencies common to vegetarianism. For example, your doctor might periodically test your children’s iron levels, or they might ask you to monitor your children for signs of a B12 deficiency, which might include fatigue, disorientation, complaining of pins and needles, speech or memory impairment, or agitation. You can also consult with a nutrition expert, if you’d like.

steps.headline: Decide what type of vegetarian diet to follow.
steps.description:
Vegetarian diets range from simply avoiding meat and poultry most of the time to going fully vegan, in which you avoid any animal products. As you contemplate changing your kids over to a vegetarian diet, think about exactly which foods you want to cut out, and which ones you’re okay with your children still eating. Some of the more common types of vegetarianism include:

Pescatarian: Eats fish and seafood, dairy, and eggs, but no meat and poultry. Lacto-ovo vegetarian: Eats dairy and eggs, but no meat, poultry, or fish. Ovo vegetarian: Eats eggs, but no dairy, meat, poultry, or fish. Lacto vegetarian: Eats dairy, but no eggs, meat, poultry, or fish. Vegan: Does not eat dairy, eggs, meat, poultry, or fish.

steps.headline: Cut out meat gradually.
steps.description: To make the transition easier, start by adding more vegetarian dishes to your meals, but still offer some meats as well. Then, gradually replace the meat in your dishes with all-vegetarian options. That way, your children’s systems will have time to adjust to having less meat and more veggies, and you’ll give them time to explore new dishes, as well. You might cut out specific types of meat one at a time. For instance, you might stop serving red meat, then after a few weeks, eliminate poultry from your children’s diet, followed by fish, then dairy.

steps.headline: Choose familiar-looking foods to start with.
steps.description: It can be hard sometimes to get kids to eat their vegetables, especially for picky eaters. If you want to introduce more vegetarian-friendly foods into your kids’ diets, try giving them all-veggie versions of foods they already enjoy. That will help picky kids overcome their initial resistance to change, and it can be a good way to teach them that food can be just as tasty without meat. Tip: For instance, you might make roasted veggie pizza, vegetarian fried rice, or vegetarian lasagna.

steps.headline: Get your kids involved in choosing and cooking foods.
steps.description: A simple trick to get your children more excited about vegetables is to ask them to help you plan, shop for, and prepare meals together. If your children feel more involved in the process, they’ll be more likely to want to eat the food they helped pick out and prepare. Older kids can help you with tasks like chopping veggies, and even small children can help with shelling beans or arranging ingredients on a pizza. If you have the space, you might even consider getting your kids involved in growing their own vegetable garden!

steps.headline: Offer iron-rich foods like avocados, beans, and peas.
steps.description: It can be a challenge to get enough iron in your diet when you’re a vegetarian. Vegans are at the highest risk for iron deficiency, while lacto-ovo vegetarians, who eat dairy and eggs, have a lower risk. However, by giving your children foods that are high in iron, and by asking their pediatrician to monitor their iron levels, you can help ensure they have a balanced diet. Other foods that are high in iron include nut and seed butters, lentils, tofu, sweet potatoes, kale, and whole grains. You can also give your children cereal that’s fortified with iron. Iron deficiency can lead to stunted growth, as well as learning and behavioral issues. Talk to your pediatrician about your child’s specific nutritional needsDid You Know? Eating vitamin C can help your body absorb iron better, so pair iron-rich veggies with foods like tomatoes, citrus fruits, melons, bell peppers, and broccoli!

steps.headline: Replace meat with beans, soy products, and dairy to provide protein.
steps.description: Meat is the most common source of protein, so make sure you’re offering plenty of protein-rich foods as you start removing meat from your children’s diets. The body uses protein to build and maintain muscles, organs, and your immune system, so this nutrient is especially essential for children. Other sources of protein include tofu, beans, peas, and lentils.

steps.headline: Provide calcium by offering dairy, leafy greens, and fortified foods.
steps.description: If you’re giving your children dairy, calcium deficiency won’t be a serious issue. However, if you’re cutting out dairy products, you’ll need to give your child plenty of calcium-rich foods like leafy greens, beans, peas, almond butter, or foods that are fortified with calcium. Calcium deficiency in children can lead to rickets, a disorder which softens the bones and stunts growth.

steps.headline: Give your children asparagus and broccoli to provide riboflavin.
steps.description: Riboflavin, also known as vitamin B2, helps provide energy and fuel growth. Most people get the recommended daily amount of riboflavin from eggs, dairy, and meats. However, many green vegetables, especially asparagus and broccoli, are rich in riboflavin. Try serving steamed broccoli or asparagus with a sprinkle of lemon pepper!

steps.headline: Soak beans, grains, and seeds until they sprout to release zinc.
steps.description: It can be hard for the body to absorb zinc, especially when the primary source is from beans, grains, and seeds. To help overcome that, try soaking these foods in cool water for several hours before you cook them. Once you see sprouts starting to form, you can cook them as you normally would. Eating leavened grain foods, like bread and crackers, might also help your body absorb zinc better.

steps.headline: Choose foods fortified with DHA|DHA to encourage growth.
steps.description: DHA, which is an omega-3 fatty acid found in fish, is an important nutrient for a child’s growth. Unless you’re a pescatarian and your family eats a lot of fish, it’s probably a good idea to add extra DHA to your child’s diet to ensure they’re getting the amount they need. Even non-vegetarian children can benefit from DHA-fortified foods, which often include juices, cereals, and even baby formula.

steps.headline: Avoid giving plant-based, milk-type drinks to children under 2.
steps.description: Beverages like soy milk and almond milk are a great substitute for regular milk, but they don’t contain enough nutrition for children who are under the age of 2. Instead, offer a soy-based formula, which is enriched with the vitamins and nutrients a baby needs to grow. Of course, talk to your doctor before you change your baby’s formula. If you’re breastfeeding, you probably do not need to supplement with soy-based formula.

steps.headline: Add in a supplement if your healthcare provider recommends it.
steps.description: Even if you’re doing your best to present your kids with a variety of healthy options at each meal and snack, they might still struggle to get the nutrients they need. If your pediatrician is concerned, they may recommend that you give your children a daily supplement, like a multivitamin or a B12 tablet. If your family follows a vegan diet, your pediatrician is more likely to recommend a daily supplement.

text:
Helping Your Kids Make the Switch Talk to your pediatrician before you change their diet. Before you make any major changes to your childrens’ diets, you should talk to your pediatrician. That way, the doctor can make any specific recommendations tailored to each child’s health needs. In addition, the doctor will know to look for specific nutritional deficiencies common to vegetarianism. For example, your doctor might periodically test your children’s iron levels, or they might ask you to monitor your children for signs of a B12 deficiency, which might include fatigue, disorientation, complaining of pins and needles, speech or memory impairment, or agitation. You can also consult with a nutrition expert, if you’d like. Decide what type of vegetarian diet to follow. Vegetarian diets range from simply avoiding meat and poultry most of the time to going fully vegan, in which you avoid any animal products. As you contemplate changing your kids over to a vegetarian diet, think about exactly which foods you want to cut out, and which ones you’re okay with your children still eating. Some of the more common types of vegetarianism include:

Pescatarian: Eats fish and seafood, dairy, and eggs, but no meat and poultry. Lacto-ovo vegetarian: Eats dairy and eggs, but no meat, poultry, or fish. Ovo vegetarian: Eats eggs, but no dairy, meat, poultry, or fish. Lacto vegetarian: Eats dairy, but no eggs, meat, poultry, or fish. Vegan: Does not eat dairy, eggs, meat, poultry, or fish. Cut out meat gradually. To make the transition easier, start by adding more vegetarian dishes to your meals, but still offer some meats as well. Then, gradually replace the meat in your dishes with all-vegetarian options. That way, your children’s systems will have time to adjust to having less meat and more veggies, and you’ll give them time to explore new dishes, as well. You might cut out specific types of meat one at a time. For instance, you might stop serving red meat, then after a few weeks, eliminate poultry from your children’s diet, followed by fish, then dairy. Choose familiar-looking foods to start with. It can be hard sometimes to get kids to eat their vegetables, especially for picky eaters. If you want to introduce more vegetarian-friendly foods into your kids’ diets, try giving them all-veggie versions of foods they already enjoy. That will help picky kids overcome their initial resistance to change, and it can be a good way to teach them that food can be just as tasty without meat. Tip: For instance, you might make roasted veggie pizza, vegetarian fried rice, or vegetarian lasagna. Get your kids involved in choosing and cooking foods. A simple trick to get your children more excited about vegetables is to ask them to help you plan, shop for, and prepare meals together. If your children feel more involved in the process, they’ll be more likely to want to eat the food they helped pick out and prepare. Older kids can help you with tasks like chopping veggies, and even small children can help with shelling beans or arranging ingredients on a pizza. If you have the space, you might even consider getting your kids involved in growing their own vegetable garden! Providing a Well-Balanced Diet Offer iron-rich foods like avocados, beans, and peas. It can be a challenge to get enough iron in your diet when you’re a vegetarian. Vegans are at the highest risk for iron deficiency, while lacto-ovo vegetarians, who eat dairy and eggs, have a lower risk. However, by giving your children foods that are high in iron, and by asking their pediatrician to monitor their iron levels, you can help ensure they have a balanced diet. Other foods that are high in iron include nut and seed butters, lentils, tofu, sweet potatoes, kale, and whole grains. You can also give your children cereal that’s fortified with iron. Iron deficiency can lead to stunted growth, as well as learning and behavioral issues. Talk to your pediatrician about your child’s specific nutritional needsDid You Know? Eating vitamin C can help your body absorb iron better, so pair iron-rich veggies with foods like tomatoes, citrus fruits, melons, bell peppers, and broccoli! Replace meat with beans, soy products, and dairy to provide protein. Meat is the most common source of protein, so make sure you’re offering plenty of protein-rich foods as you start removing meat from your children’s diets. The body uses protein to build and maintain muscles, organs, and your immune system, so this nutrient is especially essential for children. Other sources of protein include tofu, beans, peas, and lentils. Provide calcium by offering dairy, leafy greens, and fortified foods. If you’re giving your children dairy, calcium deficiency won’t be a serious issue. However, if you’re cutting out dairy products, you’ll need to give your child plenty of calcium-rich foods like leafy greens, beans, peas, almond butter, or foods that are fortified with calcium. Calcium deficiency in children can lead to rickets, a disorder which softens the bones and stunts growth. Give your children asparagus and broccoli to provide riboflavin. Riboflavin, also known as vitamin B2, helps provide energy and fuel growth. Most people get the recommended daily amount of riboflavin from eggs, dairy, and meats. However, many green vegetables, especially asparagus and broccoli, are rich in riboflavin. Try serving steamed broccoli or asparagus with a sprinkle of lemon pepper! Soak beans, grains, and seeds until they sprout to release zinc. It can be hard for the body to absorb zinc, especially when the primary source is from beans, grains, and seeds. To help overcome that, try soaking these foods in cool water for several hours before you cook them. Once you see sprouts starting to form, you can cook them as you normally would. Eating leavened grain foods, like bread and crackers, might also help your body absorb zinc better. Choose foods fortified with DHA|DHA to encourage growth. DHA, which is an omega-3 fatty acid found in fish, is an important nutrient for a child’s growth. Unless you’re a pescatarian and your family eats a lot of fish, it’s probably a good idea to add extra DHA to your child’s diet to ensure they’re getting the amount they need. Even non-vegetarian children can benefit from DHA-fortified foods, which often include juices, cereals, and even baby formula. Avoid giving plant-based, milk-type drinks to children under 2. Beverages like soy milk and almond milk are a great substitute for regular milk, but they don’t contain enough nutrition for children who are under the age of 2. Instead, offer a soy-based formula, which is enriched with the vitamins and nutrients a baby needs to grow. Of course, talk to your doctor before you change your baby’s formula. If you’re breastfeeding, you probably do not need to supplement with soy-based formula. Add in a supplement if your healthcare provider recommends it. Even if you’re doing your best to present your kids with a variety of healthy options at each meal and snack, they might still struggle to get the nutrients they need. If your pediatrician is concerned, they may recommend that you give your children a daily supplement, like a multivitamin or a B12 tablet. If your family follows a vegan diet, your pediatrician is more likely to recommend a daily supplement.
